class_notes:
(Same as ENG 752)
Faulkner was an artist (his mother painted), a poet (influenced by French and British poets of the late 19thcentury, among others), a writer of short stories, a novelist, a screenwriter, an essayist, and one of the most widely translated and influential writers of the 20th century, a Nobel Laureate. In this course, we will undertake a study of his work, with attention to his modernism and aesthetic experiments, the social and literary worlds that shaped his work, his global significance and reception, and his continuing interest for readers and writers in the 21st century.  
Texts: The Sound and the Fury, As I Lay Dying, Light in August, Absalom, Absalom!, The Wild Palms/If I Forget Thee, Jerusalem, and Go Down, Moses. Some texts provided by professor including short stories, William Faulkner: Early Prose and Poetry (ed. Carvel Collins) and New Orleans Sketches (Collins, ed.), We will examine some of his screenplays: Today We Live (1933), To Have and Have Not (1944), and The Big Sleep (1946). This is a seminar, so reading lists will be, to some extent, individualized to reflect the research interests of participants. More details on Canvas. 
Work: short responses to scholarship and criticism; individual and small-group tutorials; in-class writing; 2 major papers; research; presentations.
course_description: Intensive study of specific literary topics, e.g., questions of form or history, or concentrations on one or more authors or literary movements. May be repeated for credit when topic varies.
